snippet: The grumbling among the 15,000 volunteers at this World Cup started early, with a complaint here, a criticism there, and it grew as the weeks went on.
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column on how FIFA has treated its thousands of World Cup volunteers; they receive no housing, no paycheck and the only job training is in Portuguese; many have been griping for weeks, but not about working without a paycheck; they are upset because they did not receive tickets to any of the matches.
lead_paragraph: The grumbling among the 15,000 volunteers at this World Cup started early, with a complaint here, a criticism there, and it grew as the weeks went on.

headline.seo: World Cup 2014: Volunteers in Brazil Find Reasons to Complain
headline.main: Many Sacrifices, but Few Perks for Event’s Volunteers
headline.print_headline: Many Sacrifices, but Few Perks for Event’s Volunteers
